What is the Berom language?
The Berom language is the native language of the Berom people, one of the largest autochthonous ethnic group in Plateau State, central Nigeria
Berom AI is a chatbot for Berom Language.
Where is the Berom Language from?
The Berom language belongs to the Plateau branch of Benue–Congo, a subfamily of the large Niger–Congo language family.
Berom AI is a chatbot for Berom Language.
What are some Berom festivals?

Some Berom festivals include:
- Mandyɛng, in March/April: Harvest festival
- Tyǐ, in August: Red ochre collection festival
- Badù, in March/April: Harvest festival
- Nshok, in March/April: Harvest festival
- Worong cun, in April/May: Planting festival, celebrated after good rains
- Búná/Vwana, in August: Fonio harvest festival
- Mado, in October/November: Hunting festival celebrated for prosperity; Che people also take part
- Behwol, in February/March: Hunting festival celebrated for prosperity; Che, Boze, Anaguta, and Izere peoples also take part
- Nzem Berom, in March/April: One-week Berom festival celebrating Berom cultural identity, first celebrated in 1981
- Wusal Berom, in November: Christian festival first celebrated in 1992

How old are the Berom people?

The Berom have a link to the Nok culture, a civilization that existed between 200 BCE to 1,000 CE. Generally, the Berom speakers are identified to live in the core Jos Plateau and down the low plains of Kaduna State.
